NEW YORK
WORLD'S FAIR 1939
Mayor
M. S. NOVIK, Director
CITY OF NEW YORK
MUNICIPAL BROADCASTING SYSTEM
MUNICIPAL BUILDING
WORTH 2-5600
March 22nd, 1940
Mr. Prank E. Schooley
WILL
University of Illinois
Urbana, Illinois
My dear Frank;
How are you getting on with the stations in connection
with the Victor applications? We have just sent in our's and that is
why I thought I'd ask about you.
I thought you would he interested in knowing that
Columbia has just agreed to give us records on the same agreement
as Victor. As far.as the license is concerned, they haven't said
anything as yet, and of course, I won't mention it.
I've just spoken with Howard Evans, who just got
back from the Washington F-M Hearing. It seems that the big fellows
are fairly well agreed on not interfering with the educational
frequencies. It looks as though the educational presentations will
not take place until the first week in April.
Our Hearing for evening time starts on March 29th,
with the Mayor and will recess until April 10th to give a representative
of th£ State of Minnesota an opportunity to present their case in
behalf of WCCO. Their intervention is just a duplication of the
WCCO case about interference hazards. We hope to prove, conclusively,
the opposite - that there is no interference in their primary area
and the slight interference in their secondary area is minor in
comparasion with the interference that exists at the present time
from Louisville on 820kc and other nearby powerful channels.
Very sincerely yours,
—
Director
P.S. Will you please send me some more of the F-M special letters -
if you have them available. Thanks.
MSH; c “New York City's Own Station”—810 Kc.
114
